clinical_study.brief_title: Serum Antimullerian Hormone Levels in Patients Who Underwent Hayman Suture
clinical_study.official_title: Serum Antimullerian Hormone Levels in Patients Who Underwent Hayman Suture for Uterine Atony During Cesarean Section

lead_sponsor.agency: Kanuni Sultan Suleyman Training and Research Hospital

clinical_study.source: Kanuni Sultan Suleyman Training and Research Hospital

brief_summary.textblock: From patient charts we will review patients who had undergone cesarean section within the last 6 months and identify those who received a The Hayman uterine compression suture for uterine atony. We will also select patients who delivered a baby without recieving a Hayman suture to create a control group. Patietns will be grouped as Hayman Group if they recevied a Hayman suture during C/S and control group if thay had not recevied a Hayman suture. We will then check patient charts for post-cesarean outpatient clinic visit and select those who received ovarian reserve evaluation via hormones and antral follicle count during the visits. Finally, we are planning to investigate any correlation between Hayman suture and ovarian dysfunction.

detailed_description.textblock: Hayman suture is a common technique for uterine compression to stop bleeding due to uterine atony. Hayman described placement of two to four vertical compression sutures from the anterior to posterior uterine wall without hysterectomy. It is usually employed to overcome uterine atoy dÄ±ring cesarean section. However, since the technique is relatively new, data on its safety and efficacy arelimited to a few case reports. several complications including cavity obliteration, blood entrapment and infections have been described. However, data regarding the ovarioan function is lacking.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in anti-mullerian hormone level from baseline (precesarean) to post-cesarean
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before cesarean section and at any follow-up visit within 6 months of cesarean section

primary_outcome.measure: Change in follicle stimulating hormone level from baseline (precesarean) to post-cesarean
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before cesarean section and at any follow-up visit within 6 months of cesarean section

primary_outcome.measure: Change in luteinizing hormone level from baseline (precesarean) to post-cesarean
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before cesarean section and at any follow-up visit within 6 months of cesarean section

secondary_outcome.measure: Antral follicle count in the two study groups
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At any follow-up visit within 6 months of cesarean section

arm_group.description: Who had undergone cesarean section within the last 6 months and received a The Hayman uterine compression suture for uterine atony.
Who had undergone cesarean section within the last 6 months and did not experience neither any complication nor any additional intervention

intervention.description: Hayman suture is a common technique for uterine compression to stop bleeding due to uterine atony. Hayman described placement of two to four vertical compression sutures from the anterior to posterior uterine wall without hysterectomy. It is usually employed to overcome uterine atony during cesarean section.

study_pop.textblock: Patients who had undergone uterine artery ligation during cesarean section. Control group is age-matched postpartum patients.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- age 18- 40 years
- no systemic or endocrine diseases
- patients who had uterine artery ligation due to atony
- healthy postpartum patients as controls
Exclusion Criteria:
- patients with Polyctsitic over syndrome
- Pregnancy with IVF or oocyte donation
- Obese patients
- patients with previous/present endometriosis

facility.name: Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, University of Health Sciences, Faculty of Medicine, Kanuni Sultan Suleyman Hospital,
